Regression in R/Python

  • R
  • Python
  • The standard way of doing this in R:
model <- lm(formula = cyl ~ mpg, data = mtcars)
summary(model)

Call:
lm(formula = cyl ~ mpg, data = mtcars)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-1.8569 -0.6484  0.1205  0.5965  1.5876 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 11.26068    0.59304   18.99  < 2e-16 ***
mpg         -0.25251    0.02831   -8.92 6.11e-10 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.95 on 30 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.7262,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.7171 
F-statistic: 79.56 on 1 and 30 DF,  p-value: 6.113e-10
  • The standard way of doing this in Python:
import statsmodels.api as sm 
y = r.mtcars['cyl']
X = r.mtcars['mpg']
X = sm.add_constant(X)
model = sm.OLS(y, X)
results = model.fit()
print(results.summary())
                            OLS Regression Results                            
==============================================================================

Model:                            OLS   Adj. R-squared:                  0.717
Method:                 Least Squares   F-statistic:                     79.56

Regression Tables in R/Python

  • R
  • Python
  • Stata
  • The best way to do this in R:
library(fixest); library(modelsummary)
model1 <- feols(cyl ~ mpg, data=mtcars)
model2 <- feols(cyl ~ mpg + hp, data=mtcars)
modelsummary(list(model1, model2), output='gt', gof_map=c('nobs', 'r.squared'))
Tables in R
(1) (2)
(Intercept) 11.261 7.629
(0.593) (1.226)
mpg -0.253 -0.154
(0.028) (0.039)
hp 0.011
(0.003)
Num.Obs. 32 32
R2 0.726 0.800
  • The best way to do this in Python:
import pyfixest as pf
fit1 = pf.feols(fml="cyl ~ mpg", data=r.mtcars)
fit2 = pf.feols(fml="cyl ~ mpg + hp", data=r.mtcars)
pf.etable([fit1, fit2])
